head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Posing As A Lawyer

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Posing As A Lawyer

body.head.byline: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS; Compiled by John Sullivan

block.p: A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer at a major New York law firm for four years -- even though, prosecutors said, he had never gone to law school -- pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of impersonating a lawyer and stealing at least $284,350 in salary from his firm. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, was promoted from paralegal to lawyer at the firm, Anderson Kill & Olick, in 2002, and was earning $155,000 plus bonuses when he was fired in October 2006, prosecutors said. His lawyer, Joseph R. Conway, said Mr. Valery, who is now unemployed, faced related charges in Connecticut and expected to have charges brought against him in Brooklyn.
